results.notes:
On thicker branches of a standing dead oak tree (Quercus agrifolia). Growing in hundreds. Those of the typical vinaceous color were a minority, most of the others were perhaps just old and faded. But there were a few that looked fresh and almost white.

Basidia 4-spored, ~ 23+7 x 14. Spore 7.5-9.5 × 6.5-9.5, amyloid. Cheilocystidia forming a band, difficult to extricate, ~27×12, with excrescences up to 8.5 microns long. Caulocystidia as long as 72 microns.

notes_fields.Habitat: Found in open deciduous woods from which pine trees had been removed. Appeared to be growing in soil. It was growing approximately 4 feet (1.2m) from an old pine tree stump; assumed to be growing on submerged roots.
notes_fields.Cap/upper_surface: Ca. 4.5 inches (11.5 cm) diameter, with a single stem. Cap circular, depressed in center; concentric zones of brown with a cream-yellow margin. Cap surface ‘felted’ appearance (wet when found). Margin bruised brown.
notes_fields.Cap/underside:
Pore surface gold-brown, with slot-like pores; bruised brown.
Cross-section. Pores, ca 2-3mm deep. Flesh "fibrous’ with two different color zones.
notes_fields.Stipe: ca. 1 inch (2.5 cm) diameter; easily cut, almost ‘watery.’
notes_fields.Chemistry: Stains black with KOH (3%), cherry red and then turning black immediately.

results.notes:
Eco region: NT0166 Amazon Moist Forests

Substrate:On wood – dead, fallen branch.

Habit: Grouped, multiple individuals inches apart, not from a common base.

Pileus 1.1-2.6cm, tough, leathery, umbillicate becoming planar to broadly depressed, surface dry, smooth, deep red-brown, darkens and spots with drying, sudden depression in surface over stipe darker in color, margin smooth to wavy, even, light gray hymenal surface, light brown context, tubes ending in pores, about 12 pores per mm.

Stipe 1.7-7.1cm x 0.1-0.2cm (at base), equal, tough, leathery, solid, medial to pileus to slightly off-center, dry, smooth, dark brown to black.

results.notes: A large growth of lichen on old cement retaining wall at the head of a drainage basin, worn to the point that much of the coarse rock aggregate is exposed. Maybe some Xanthoria candelaria (image # 4101) and possibly Caloplaca citrina (image # 4091). I can’t even venture a guess on the others, which may or may not represent a variety of species.

results.notes:
I’m seeing a lot of grey Tricholomas here that are confusing me. It seems like there’s intermediate forms everywhere between these typical-looking T. griseoviolaceum(?) and dry chunky scaly ones that don’t look like any photos labeled T. g. They all have a very faintly farinaceous smell and faintly farinaceous taste. Either T. g. has a lot more variation than I thought (after seeing everything at LAMS last year) or there is at least one other grey Trich present here.
I’m gonna split up the obses and hopefully match herbarium specimens up with them. Again, this obs is the “obvious” griseoviolaceum, I think…?

results.notes:
I’m seeing a lot of grey Tricholomas here that are confusing me. It seems like there’s intermediate forms everywhere between typical-looking T. griseoviolaceum(?) and dry chunky scaly ones that don’t look like any photos labeled T. g. They all have a very faintly farinaceous smell and faintly farinaceous taste. Either T. g. has a lot more variation than I thought (after seeing everything at LAMS last year) or there is at least one other grey Trich present here.
I’m gonna split up the obses and hopefully match herbarium specimens up with them. This obs seems like griseoviolaceum with way more white than it “should” have… which wouldn’t worry me but this mostly-white type seemed much more common than the mostly grey-violet type.
Many specimens had skimpy but distinct dark annulus zones.

results.notes:
I’m confused and upset by the blurry line between “this” and ferruginans, growing in the same area. These are some of the most solid not-ferruginans specimens, which tend to have (1) more yellowish-brownish rather than greyish caps, (2) no bleach smell under the gills, (3) a farinaceous smell at the stem base, and (4) a strange pleasant smell after some time has passed after being picked.
The solidly bleachy ones (staying bleachy or becoming foul after picking) are much more common.
But it seems like there are mushrooms in between obvious ferruginans and obvious “lividoalbum”, and often it’s strangely hard for me to even get a consistent smell from a single specimen of these. Plus, it looks like ferruginans have more of this lividoalbum color when they have been exposed to less light.

results.notes:
Sandy restored tallgrass prairie with forest on either side and a few seedlings and saplings present throughout the grassland.

Microscopy notes on spores 2017-02-17
Shape varied from almost globose to more bean-shaped (perhaps they only appeared different from different viewing angles).
Apiculus visible
Not smooth – has fine dots (warts)
Size (min-avg-max 10 measured)
L: 6.5-7.7-8.0um
W: 5.5-6.0-6.5um

The best fit is Laccaria laccatta (a small form). The spores are on the smaller end but still within range.
L. ohiensis I didn’t know to check wart-base size at the time, but it has larger spores than mine here.
L. trullissata has much larger spores and looks nothing like this, despite the habitat matching perfectly.

results.notes:
Growing on a decaying log, probably oak.

Stipe somewhat tough/flexible.

I managed to collect a spore print that was just deep enough to observe the white color. Spore drop occupied a very small area area on a microscope slide. I mounted in Meltzer’s, but there was a bit of tiny debris on the slide, which prevented the slip from forming a seal with the liquid mount. So I needed try to wipe away material from the slip. I managed to get the slip to rest correctly on the slide, but lost some spores in the process. I found a few spores, and it appears the walls are darkened to the extent that one may call this an amyloid reaction, albeit, perhaps weakly so. Spores are elliptical, many quite regularly, without pores or appendages observed. Dimensions approximately 7-10 × 5-6.

results.notes:
Substrate: Growing on roots which were about an inch below the soil.

Habit: Multiple scattered fruiting bodies.

Pileus: Conical to fan shaped. Thin and dry, yet flexible. When mature- Pileus height: 25-35 mm; Pileus diameter: 25-30 mm. No pores present, instead short, thick, dark hairs covering hymenial surface. When immature- Pileus diameter greatly reduced and entire specimen appears rod-shaped. Rusty orange with cream bands streaking through. When young, turns a light cream color towards the margin; When old the margin turns dark grey to black and becomes erose, as if it was singed by fire.

Stipe: Often the stipes of what appear to be two different pilei twist and fuse together making the diameter of the stipes very variable. Height varies between: 25-40 mm. Often half of the stipe is found underneath the soil substrate, becoming increasingly more gnarled and fused the lower down it is. Velvety texture with a dry, almost spongy context. Rust orange. Knobby and gnarled in form.

Ecoregion: NT0166
Southwest Amazon Moist Forests

Collected for the 2017 SUNY-ESF Fungi of Bolivia Field Course & 2nd Field Workshop on Neotropical Polypores

results.notes:
unfortunately, this is the only picture that came out, but thought I may as well post anyways.
on a grassy hill under mixed oak woods

Smoky gray cap, becoming substantially lighter toward the whitish, bright translucent-striate margin. Gills creamy white. No odor. To me, I see a faint bluish tint to the cool gray stipe, which is curved and subtly larger at the base, but I that may be arguable. Live oak associated, not with conifers or wood chips.
All surfaces were smooth and dry. Phaeocyanopus is possible with the habitat and appearance, but may be too dark for this mushroom, as it would probably be a younger one given the pale, less blue stipe. The stipe tones and small size is making me lean toward the nanus group. I know that genetically the “nanus” here is distinctive from old world nanus types. In Eurasia, nanus can grow with quercus, but I don’t know if that is the case with California specimens of the Nanus group. According to the 12 new species of holarctic pluteus section pluteus paper, americanus and salicinus are not known from here. The other possibility I am aware about would be the pluteus thomsonii group. What little I have found about thomsonii does not match the photograph so well.

results.notes:
Substrate: Sandy soil close to the trunk of an immature hardwood tree.

Habit: 5-6 fruiting bodies within a 1 m^2 patch of soil, well spaced apart for the most part.

Pileus: Ranging in maturity. 20-30 mm height; 30-40 mm diameter. Umbonate shape. Entire margin, slightly rounded when immature. Light brown with dense dark brown striations.

Hymenium:Pink lamellae with entire edges, closely spaced.

Stipe: 30-40 mm height, 5-10 mm diameter. Finely striate, flaring very slightly at base. White colored, graying slightly near base.

Comments: The specimens I found were covered in the mycelium of another species, presumably consuming them. I wonder if the infection began before the prey’s fruiting, and this was a last-ditch effort to reproduce, or rather the infection started after the fruiting and the predator is just coincidentally thwarting the prey’s effort to reproduce. Only one of the collected fruiting bodies had fully matured and opened.

Ecoregion: NT0166
Southwest Amazon Moist Forests

results.notes:
Substrate: Soil covered by leaf litter.

Habit: Solitary.

Pileus: 30 mm diameter, 2-3 mm thickness, thinner at margins, thicker near center. Infundibuliform, with center sinking slightly and margin only slightly curved down. Surface texture resembling chicken skin with bumps on surface in accordance with the hyemenial pattern. Fine light hairs 1-2 mm in length line the thin margin, horizontally pointing away from the center of the pileus. Pale orange/peach except for the very center and margin where it darkens to a light brown.

Hymenial surface slightly decurrent to stipe. Pores hexagonal and very pale yellow, and slightly darker closer to the margin.

Stipe: 50 mm height, 5 mm diameter near cap, 6 mm diameter near base. Smooth for the most part. Grey striations occasionally present but rubbing off, leaving a smooth, leaving a pale yellow/light tan surface. Fibrilose flesh texture, even paler yellow inside.

Ecoregion: NT0166

results.notes:
NEED HELP WITH IDENTIFICATION! Found these in 2 locations (roughly 1 mile apart) in PA SGL 110. Don’t think these are strictly fungi. Thought they might be Lichenomphalia, but can’t find a species that fits. I’ve searched and viewed every lichen image on MO and stalked lichens on discoverlife.org, as well as, other sites. Plan to upload to iSpot as well.

Remained fruiting from July until fall.

I don’t know lichens well enough to use exact terms in describing, but I’ll do my best.

Caps: up to 1 cm at maturity, creamy white, smooth on top, chanterelle-like with ribs (not gills) underneath.

Stalks: .5 – 1 cm long, elongated barrel shape when young, becoming curved, wavy or even bent with some having round nodules (as if they swallowed a pea), scaly like that of Cladonia species (squamules or soredia??).

Habitat: among moss at base of standing dead hemlocks; near banks of Northkill Creek.

results.notes:
I was looking at the pictures of the recent Rinodina field trip and found very interesting material. One of these is this beautiful lichen to which I did not devote much attention in the field and so do not even take a sample of it (but I will return there within a few weeks). The fact is that now it does not resemble Caloplaca, which at the time I thought to be, but one that I asked myself several times when will find it. I think of it as having all the characteristics of an Ophioparma, namely:

- Growing on siliceous rock;
- A clearly warted areolate thallus, light coloured (whitish?), with some hues of sulphur (yellow-green marks, best seen magnifying the photo);
- Great orange-red matt apothecia (perhaps more than 1.5 mm in diameter), discs slightly convex to almost flat, dispersed by the small talus;
- Apothecia with a big thaline rim, concolor with the thallus, that seems to extend bellow the apothecia;
- A K+ blue-violet (maybe also some hues of pink and magenta) reaction on thallus and on apothecia, where it is more intense (can be due to haemoventosin, the specific pigment of Ophioparma).
results.location_name: Serra de São Mamede, Portugal

results.notes:
Substrate: Fallen hardwood.

Habit: 10 to 12 fruiting bodies of varying maturity found on log.

Fruiting bodies: Widths vary between 60-80 mm, height (thickness) between 1 and 2 mm. Much thicker at base (~10-15 mm). Sessile. Upper pileus covered in dense, thick, erect dark brown hairs roughly 3 mm long. Hairs of lower individuals covered in light colored spores. Margin entire and horizontal, slightly lighter in color. Pileus color mostly dark brown with occasional chestnut brown concentric rings. Hymenial surface covered in small, dense pores. Pores mixture of round and geometric.

results.notes:
Growing on small branch, approximately 0.5 inches diameter. Found on ground after branch had fallen from large hardwood tree growing on floodplain above a small creek.
This fungus fruits with a bracket approximately 1-1.5 inches diameter. Subsequently a ‘cap,’ approximately 0.5 inches diameter develops near the attachment point of the first bracket. With time, the larger bracket falls off, leaving the small, sterile caps. (See: http://www.projectnoah.org/spottings/1803556002)
These are the caps that remained after the larger brackets fell off. Caps are white with concentric rings of brown or gray colors; have small stems; with large pores.

results.notes:
No scent, spores fairly dark for a russula, under old coast live oak in damp area.
Purple color, medium size. Lack of aroma and gills remaining whitish in age and stipe handling eliminate xerampelina group. Spore color clearly eliminates cyanoxantha group.
Mendocinensis eliminated by habitat, range and details above.
Spores straw colored, buffy yellow. Would appreciate any information on some of the more unusual purple varieties that can show up here.
Cap tones remind me of olivacea, but wrong habitat, and can probably be eliminated by stipe and odor. Chameleontina eliminated by lack of odor or striated margin. Cessans wrong habitat, stipe likely too long, cap not easily peeling, etc.
Unlikely to be turci with no chemical smell at base, plus habitat and other features.
Nothing changed to orange or dark when cut= not occidentalis group supposedly.
Grisea probably eliminated by habitat and gills being too pale. Abietina should have striated margin, and unlikely habitat\location. The unstriated margin also should elimiate lilacea and puellaris. Quelletii group should show more stipe color, plus very unlikely due to habitat and being odorless. It seems the cap tones might be outside range. Pelargonia should have an odor, pink stipe wash, etc. Placita should be pruinose and grow with conifers. Spores too dark for vinacea, atropurpurea and fragilis.
Possible: murillii, though cap may be too big. appears that sometimes it is in dark oak areas in CA, but not sure.
Possible: brunneoviolacea, habitat good, cap with paler and brownish and yellow tones at center, potential yellowish brown stain at stipe base, but if so weak and taking long to develop. May not have peeled apart easily enough to be this species, and could be too aged to have unstriated margin. Cap and stipe size work.

results.notes:
On calcareous rock in semi-arid grassland setting, west facing slope in full sun.

Thallus rimose-areolate, thick, brown, with areole margins lifting in maturity but not becoming subsquamulose, lacking prothallus, C-, K-. Apothecia starting immersed becoming somewhat superficial, disk black, roughened, concave to plane, margin concolorous with thallus, raised. Hymenium and hypothecium hyaline, epihymenium red-brown, K-

Spores 8/ascus, broadly ellipsoid, hyaline to gray to brown, swollen at septa, not ornmented. I think these are Bischoffi-type with rounded lumina, separate wall layers visible at septum. Average 20.9×14.0. (19.9×12.0, 23.5×17.0, 19.9×12.0, 22.5×12.5, 20.4×14.4, 19.5×15.3, 20.7×14.7). Size is a little large for R. bischoffii.

results.notes:
On old decorticated wood of a Valley Oak (Quercus lobata) stump along a small riparian corridor.

Thallus thin, granular to irregularly lumpy (seemingly mixed with esorediate thallus of Lecanora saligna), greenish grey, K+reddish brown. Apothecia black, mazadiate, with a very fine diffuse pruina. Mazadeium blueish under compound scope. POL-. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium brown.

Spores brown, 1-septate, ellipsoid, sometimes constricted at septum, with micro-ornamentation, average size 13.8×7.2µm (n=7).

results.notes:
On sandstone bedrock, northwest facing.

Thallus of grey areoles with white mottling, rather thick, with a black prothallus. Cortex very strongly K+R. Medulla white, I-, K+orangish red slowly. Apothecia large, to over 1.5mm, with concave to slightly convex black roughened disk, always with pruina, sometimes compound, sunken into areoles with thin whitish raised margin. Hymenium hyaline +/-90µm tall?, hypothecium hyaline, epihymenium dark without aeruginous colors. Paraphyses moniliform. Pycnidia not found.

Spores 8/ascus, hyaline, ellipsoid, simple, large: 29.3×16.9, 28.5×14.2µm.

results.notes:
Growing in clusters on hardwood log.
Largest cap, ca. 1.5 inches diameter; high convex.
Gills attached (although they don’t appear attached in the cross-sectional photos).
Stem white at top, dark near base; hollow; tough; annulus present. No distinctive odor. KOH (3%); red-brown staining on cap.
Spore print brown.
Spores subellipsoid, verrucose, 7-9µ x 4-5µ.
